explosives.rationale: There are no chemical groups associated with explosive properties present in the molecules.

self_reactive_substances.rationale: There are no chemical groups associated with explosive or self-reactive properties present in the molecule.

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures, which in contact with water, emit flammable gases

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: Melting point: 732degC (ICSC, 2002). Test methods applicable to solid substances are not available.

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: SPECIES: Rat ENDPOINT: LD50 VALUE: 1100 mg/kg REFERENCE SOURCE: EU-RAR (2004)

acute_toxicity_dermal.rationale: It was set as Category 2 based on guinea pig LD50 = 173mg/kg (IUCLID (2000)).

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.rationale: LC50 value decided for the animal is not acquired. But the humans deaths after exposure is reported though an exposure level was unknown (ACGIH (2001), PATTY (5th, 2001)). Therefore, it was set to category 1-5.

skin_corrosion_irritation.hazard_statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: The dermal surface inflammatory change and ulcers are observed in rabbit skin irritation test (EU-RAR (2004)). Also formations of pustule and vesicles on skin in human patch test were reported (DFGOTvol.19 (2002)). Therefore it was classified as Category 1A-1C.

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: An eye has in an accident two reports of the humans who received concentrated zinc chlorides exposure (EU-RAR (2004)). It resulted in cornea cicatrization permanent subsequently to edema, and was set as Category 1 based on description (EU-RAR (2004)) that recovery took 6 - 28 weeks.

respiratory_skin_sensitizer.classification: Respiratory sensitization: Classification not possible; Skin sensitization: Classification not possible
respiratory_skin_sensitizer.rationale: [Respiratory sensitization] The occupational asthmas by soldering flux has been reported by humans (DFGOTvol.19 (2002)) but causes are unknown. since they are also exposed to ammonium chlorides. Therefore, it cannot be classified. [Skin sensitization] No data

germ_cell_mutagenicity.hazard_statement: Suspected of causing genetic defects (state route of exposure if it is conclusively proven that no other routes of exposure cause the hazard)
germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: The substance was classified as Category 2. Based on the positive results from the chromosome aberration tests using rats and mice (the in vivo mutagenicity test in somatic cells) (EU-RAR (2004), EHC 221(2001)).

carcinogenicity.rationale: Presently there is no institution which has defined the classification Category about the carcinogenicity of the zinc chloride. Each existing long-term animal examination (DFGOT vol.19 (2002)) has defect on protocol as a carcinogenicity tests, and the data which can be utilized about the carcinogenicity of zinc itself is also restricted. EU and U.S. also stated that carcinogenic evaluation has insufficient information (IRIS (2006), EU-RAR (2004)). From the above thing, since data was insufficient, it determined "It cannot be classified."

toxic_to_reproduction.hazard_statement: Suspected of damaging fertility or the undorn child
toxic_to_reproduction.rationale: Based in the reduction of the number of littermates in the dose causing general toxicity of maternal animals (DFGOTvol.19 (2002)), it is classified into the Category 2

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organs/systemic toxicity following single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_statement: Cause damage to organs (respiratory, liver, pancreas)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: The artery occlusions in the lungs and fibrosis, cyanosis, ARDS syndrome, etc. are reported in humans after inhalation exposure (ACGIH (7th 2001), PATTY (5th, 2001), and the symptoms includes the irritation to nose, the throat, and the respiratory tracts in addition to nausea, cough, etc. (EU-RAR (2004), ACGIH (7th, 2001)). Furthermore, there is the report of liver damages and pancreatic achylias by oral ingestion (EHC 221 (2001)). It was classified into Category 1 (respiratory system, liver, pancreas) based on these information.

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organs/systemic toxicity following repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement: Causes damage to organs (lung, liver) through prolonged or repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: In addition to the lung lymphocytic infiltration and the fatty degeneration of the liver, with higher concentrations, high death rates is seen with a mouse by inhalation exposure (DFGOT vol.19 (2002)). It was classified in Category 1 (lungs, liver) by comparing toxic effect concentrations seen in murine lung and liver with the guidance value.

acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: It was classified into Category 1 from 48-hour EC50=0.1mg/L of Crustacea (Daphnia magna) (CERI Hazard Data, 2002).

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_statement: Very toxic to aquatic life with long lasting effects
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Classified into Category 1, since acute toxicity was Category 1, and it is a metallic compound, behavior in water is unknown., though less bioaccumulative (BCF=178 (existing chemical safety inspections data)).
